attributes.title: The Influence of Color on Visual Integration

q1.value: Updated Pre-registration – The Influence of Color on Visual Integration

q3.value:
This pre-registration is an update to the previously submitted pre-registration. It builds on the results of that experiment using a modified procedure to examine the same migration effect. For an outline of the background on this project, please see the main pre-registration entitled “The Influence of Color on Visual Integration.”

After conducting the previous experiment (Experiment 1) we observed a significant color matching effect (excluding trials on which participants reported were guesses as specified in the original preregistered study). The proportion of hits for color-matched and color mismatched trials was 0.712 (SD = 0.150) and 0.680 (SD = 0.166), respectively, t(91) = 3.93, p < .001 , dz = 0.409.

To determine if the color-matching effect would be enhanced by eliminating the sudden onset of the frame (a form), in Experiment 2, the method will be the same except that a grayscale mosaic frame will be present throughout the sequence (beginning with the fixation point). Simultaneous with the onset of the target picture, the frame will display the same colors as in Experiment 1. Thus the frame (the form) will be a fixture in the sequence and participants will report which picture was present when the color appeared. This experiment is intended to test the effects of color with the removal of any effect of the sudden effect of surrounding form (frame onset).

Two changes from the preregistration for Experiment 1 include:

1) Changes to testing for color-blindness: We now prescreen for color-blindness on SONA (self-report).  And we have added the classic Ishihara test plates (Ishihara, 1917), which are mosaics made of irregular shapes of different colors. When viewed with normal color vision, a numeral can be seen in each of the plates. Two of these plates (corresponding to red/green and blue/yellow) will be presented to participants at the end of the study. If they cannot see the number on either plate their data will be excluded from analysis.

2) In the last experiment we conducted a task after the main experiment to determine how well participant thought the frame and target pictures matched or mismatched. In this new Experiment will approach this same goal in a different way, focusing on participants’ experience given a brief presentation (similar to the sequence). Each target will be on screen for 1.3 s (the duration of a sequence in the migration study) with the monochrome mosaic frame around it). About halfway through the sequence a color mosaic (matching on one trial, mismatching on another) will appear for 111 ms. Participants rate the match between the target and color mosaic as: excellent, good, fair, poor, none. All 24 target pictures will be tested (once with the matching color mosaic and once with the mismatching color mosaic), yielding 48 trials.

q4.value:
1) Will the color-matching effect occur under these new conditions? Analysis will be the same as in Experiment 1. 

2) If it does occur, will the color-matching effect be enhanced by eliminating the onset of a form (the frame is always on-screen)? To assess this, we plan to compare the results of this experiment to those of Experiment 1. A 2 (frame + color onset vs. color onset) x 2 (match/mismatch).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: In this repeated measures study, there will be one treatment group. All participants will be blind to the experiment's hypothesis, as there will be no mention of color matching before or during the migration procedure.

question.value: This design is the same as in the Experiment 1 preregistration.

q9.value: Across participants, which trials are matched and mismatched will be balanced across two counterbalancing conditions. The order of trials in each of these conditions are then reversed to yield the final four orders. Participants will be assigned to one of four orders in a sequential fashion, until the predetermined number of participants is reached.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Same as in Experiment 1, with the addition of pre-screening for self-reported color blind individuals.

q13.value: Target sample size is 92 participants (same as in Experiment 1).

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .8 power to detect a small-medium effect size (dz = 0.4; based on the effect found in Experiment 1) at the standard .05 alpha error probability. The yielded a required sample size of 49. However, to maintain the same design, we decided to run 92 participants to match the number run in Experiment 1.

question.value: Same as in Experiment 1
Same as in Experiment 1.
Same as in Experiment 1.

Statistical analyses will be the same as in Experiment 1. An additional analysis will compare the results of Experiment 1 and Experiment 2 using a 2 (frame + color onset vs. color onset) x 2 (match/mismatch) mixed ANOVA.

summary.value: This is a preregistration document for a class research project.

attributes.title: Public (RE devel)
attributes.description: Publicly shared information about this project, including Registered study protocol versions, etc.

q1.value: Developing Reward-Enhanced ERP (RE-ERP) as a novel treatment for tic disorders: Aim 2

q2.value: Kevin J. Black, Kimberly Sirl, John Piacentini, Melanie VanDyke

q3.value: We propose to modify exposure and response prevention (ERP) by adding automated, in-session immediate rewards for brief tic-free periods, or reward-enhanced ERP (RE-ERP). Aim 2 describes a pilot study to confirm target engagement (increased tic suppression efficacy with treatment) in children age 7-17 with Tourette syndrome or chronic motor or vocal tic disorder (TS/CTD).

q4.value: Within-session, immediately rewarded tic suppression ability will increase over the course of RE-ERP treatment.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: Video-based tic rating from before and after RE-ERP will be done after randomizing the order of the videos so that the rater is blind to whether the video was recorded before or after treatment. Other data analyses are not blind to treatment or order effects.

question.value: The Aim 2 study involves a within-subject analysis of a single treatment group.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants are recruited as a convenience sample by referral and advertising. They meet inclusion and exclusion criteria listed on page 9 of the attached file ("Page 72" in the footer). Participants are paid $125 for each of two visits (screening/baseline and post-treatment). Planned timeline: see attached document. Tic suppression efficacy is defined for the two in-person visits based on expert scoring of the videos blind to time point (pre- vs post-treatment). Analyses between these visits are based on a parent noting tics on free-to-tic videos and in subsequent treatment sessions.

q13.value: Aim 2 is planned for 20 people enrolled and 16 completing treatment. If no substantive changes to the treatment protocol occurred since the start of Aim 1 (initial pilot testing), the 10-13 participants from Aim 1 will be added to the Aim 2 subjects for analysis.

q14.value:
* During-treatment analysis: The total number of participants in Aims 1 and 2 gives approximately 80% power to detect a significant increase in the target (slope significantly greater than zero; see Milestones section for details), with an effect size d = 0.5 and α = 0.05 (estimated as power for a one-tailed, one-sample t test, mean slope > 0).
* Pre- vs post-treatment analysis: 26 subjects will achieve about 80% power to detect an increase in tic suppression efficacy from the pre-treatment to the post-treatment visit (estimated as a one-tailed paired t test).

question.value: Single treatment arm, about 8 weeks of RE-ERP therapy at home.

The key dependent variable, tic suppression efficacy E, is based on the mean number of 10-second tic-free intervals per minute during a given RE-ERP session (S) and the mean number of 10-second tic-free intervals per minute during the most recent “free to tic, alone” video (A), as follows: E = (S − A) / (6 − A) (optionally multiplied by 100%). S and A range from 0.0 (ticcing at least every 10 s) to 6.0 (no tics). A suppression efficacy score of E = 0 means no suppression during the session, while a score of E = 100% occurs only with complete suppression during the session. If there are no tics in the “free to tic, alone” condition, the formula above does not work, and we will set E = 100% but track such data separately.
See above for definition of E. See analysis section for use of slopes for analysis of within-treatment data, and for possible addition of significant covariates or factors.

Between-visits analysis: This analysis will use a linear mixed model approach [6] with patient intercept and slope over time as random factors, using data from all treatment sessions lasting at least 5 minutes. The primary comparison is the trend over time in E (i.e., slope), with a significance threshold of p ≤ .05 (one tail, hypothesizing slope > 0, i.e. improved within-session, immediately rewarded tic suppression over time). If a nonlinear model such as a sigmoid curve fits the data for course of improvement over time substantially better (by a model comparison F test, adjusting for the number of model parameters), we will substitute that for the linear analysis. Baseline tic severity, age, sex, comorbidity (ADHD Rating Scale and CY-BOCS scores) and medication status (binary variables for each of 5 classes of common medications) will be added to the model if they explain a significant fraction of the variance in the primary outcome measure. As a check, key results will also be examined in subjects with no medication treatment and no diagnosis of ADHD or OCD (the most common comorbidities).
Pre- vs post-treatment analysis: Similar except it will be essentially a paired t test (plus significant covariates or factors as noted above) comparing post- to pre-treatment tic suppression efficacy within subject, paired.

q20.value: As above: If a nonlinear model such as a sigmoid curve fits the data for course of improvement over time substantially better (by a model comparison F test, adjusting for the number of model parameters), we will substitute that for the linear analysis.

q21.value: p < .05 for each analysis above, one-tailed tests as we have a specific hypothesis.

q22.value: Prior to analyses above, any score >3 SD beyond the group mean will be removed from the analysis.

q23.value:
Between-visits analysis: Any participant who has completed less than 4 weeks of RE-ERP treatment will be excluded, 
Pre- vs post-treatment analysis: Any participant who does not return for the post-treatment visit will be excluded.

q24.value:
* We will examine YGTSS, CGI-I, PTQ and Rush video score data by comparing group mean improvement after including significant factors or covariates as described for the primary analysis above.
* We will examine how the clinical outcome measures correlate with target engagement, again with covariates as noted.
* We will test for information about the mechanism of improvement; namely, whether clinical improvement correlates best to tic suppression, response inhibition more broadly, habituation to urge, or a change in self-efficacy (see Table in the Approach section of the attached file for these variables). Additional secondary analyses will examine predictive variables (such as whether improvement depends on treatment adherence or ADHD) and secondary outcome measures (such as whether BATS score or GTS-QoL scores improve with successful treatment).

q25.value:
See the attached files for any missing details. 
NOTE: After submission on 2020-02-14 (corresponding to the attached files), I noticed errors in the power section of the analysis plan (should read increase not decrease, greater not less than zero, and "paragraph above" not "Milestones section"). I also realized that the attached document does not describe the analysis of the post- vs. pre-treatment tic suppression efficacy data. These errors have been corrected in this registration.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

other.value:
While the underlying data have already been collected and made public, we have blinded ourselves to the relationship between our variables by creating two placebo DVs. We randomly reshuffled EMS across our cases, thus preventing us from learning anything about the predictive power of our mediator and covariates (since they were just predicting random noise, albeit random noise with the same distributional properties as our actual data) in the building of our models. After submitting this registration, we will then shift to the real variable and will run the registered models.
This registration is a follow-up to https://osf.io/6q25d, which we have already run. The ideas for this analysis came from discussions of those prior results at lab meetings and among the authors. We therefore know a little bit more about the data than in the previous analysis, where we were truly blind to the relationships between our variables - we know, for instance, that there was an interaction between political orientation and our time-changepoint for the prediction of EMS. However, we still do not know the relationships with the DV in this data.

sample.value: Our sample is based on those individuals with full data. We have 37,719 participants who meet our criteria, which gives us far better than 80% power to detect a mediation effect with small (standardized beta = 0.14) a and b paths (Fritz & MacKinnon, 2007)

analyses.value:
We are conducting a moderated mediation, with a time-dummy (coded as 0 if the response comes before the election of Donald Trump and 1 if the response comes from afterwards) moderating the mediational relationship where political orientation (binned as 0 if self-reporting Democratic leanings and 1 if self-reporting Republican leanings) -> (a path) -> changes in EMS -> (b path) changes in explicit attitudes.
We predict that these relationships will not hold in the same pattern for a parallel analysis using IMS as the mediator.

 See the commented analysis script in the Analysis component of this registration.

outliers.value: We will exclude any participants who do not have responses in our mediator as well as excluding those with missing values in our IV, or DV, or our demographic covariates. We will additionally exclude anyone reporting themselves to be politically neutral and will drop anyone reporting that they were born before 1925 (to exclude those individuals of high leverage who misunderstood our free-response age question).

dependent.value:
Our IV is binned political orientation, based on a 7-point question that asks respondents about their political leanings. We code those with Republican leanings (i.e. those answering from 1 to 3 on the scale) as 1, and code those with Democratic leanings (i.e. those answering from 5 to 7) as 0. We drop anyone who responded as Neutral (i.e. 4).
Our mediating variable is the Internal/External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice scale (Plant & Devine, 1998), which was collected from a random subset of participants who took the Race IAT on Project Implicit from 2015-2018. Specifically, we’re using the EMS subscale
Our DV is a composite of three explicit attitude variables - a difference-score for feeling thermometers towards black and white individuals (scored as white-black) and an explicit-preference item from 1 = “I strongly prefer African Americans to European Americans” to 7 = “I strongly prefer European Americans to African Americans.”). We standardized both the difference score and the explicit preference item, then averaged them together to create our DV.

conditions.value: There are no experimental conditions - all participants responded to the same set of questions.

hypothesis.value:
In prior analysis of this data, we have found that those self-identifying as Republicans reported lower External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice (Plant & Devine, 1998) after the election of Donald Trump, while self-identified Democrats showed no such change. 
In the current analysis, we test whether this change in motivation further predicts changes in explicit attitudes towards African-Americans. Using a moderated-mediation framework, we predict that one’s political orientation predicts EMS, which predicts explicit attitudes, and that the relationship between political attitudes and EMS will change from before to after the election of Donald Trump (Republicans will report less EMS), which will predict increased prejudice against African-Americans for Republicans (but not for Democrats).

registration_responses.data: Yes, we already collected the data.
registration_responses.name: TrumpEMS Study 2

After submitting this registration, we will then shift to the real variable and will run the registered models.
This registration is a follow-up to https://osf.io/6q25d, which we have already run. The ideas for this analysis came from discussions of those prior results at lab meetings and among the authors. We therefore know a little bit more about the data than in the previous analysis, where we were truly blind to the relationships between our variables - we know, for instance, that there was an interaction between political orientation and our time-changepoint for the prediction of EMS. However, we still do not know the relationships with the DV in this data.

sample.value: Our sample is based on those individuals with full data. We have 37,719 participants who meet our criteria, which gives us far better than 80% power to detect a mediation effect with small (standardized beta = 0.14) a and b paths (Fritz & MacKinnon, 2007)

analyses.value:
We are conducting a moderated mediation, with a time-dummy (coded as 0 if the response comes before the election of Donald Trump and 1 if the response comes from afterwards) moderating the mediational relationship where political orientation (binned as 0 if self-reporting Democratic leanings and 1 if self-reporting Republican leanings) -> (a path) -> changes in EMS -> (b path) changes in explicit attitudes.
We predict that these relationships will not hold in the same pattern for a parallel analysis using IMS as the mediator.

 See the commented analysis script in the Analysis component of this registration.

outliers.value: We will exclude any participants who do not have responses in our mediator as well as excluding those with missing values in our IV, or DV, or our demographic covariates. We will additionally exclude anyone reporting themselves to be politically neutral and will drop anyone reporting that they were born before 1925 (to exclude those individuals of high leverage who misunderstood our free-response age question).

dependent.value:
Our IV is binned political orientation, based on a 7-point question that asks respondents about their political leanings. We code those with Republican leanings (i.e. those answering from 1 to 3 on the scale) as 1, and code those with Democratic leanings (i.e. those answering from 5 to 7) as 0. We drop anyone who responded as Neutral (i.e. 4).
Our mediating variable is the Internal/External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice scale (Plant & Devine, 1998), which was collected from a random subset of participants who took the Race IAT on Project Implicit from 2015-2018. Specifically, we’re using the EMS subscale
Our DV is a composite of three explicit attitude variables - a difference-score for feeling thermometers towards black and white individuals (scored as white-black) and an explicit-preference item from 1 = “I strongly prefer African Americans to European Americans” to 7 = “I strongly prefer European Americans to African Americans.”). We standardized both the difference score and the explicit preference item, then averaged them together to create our DV.

conditions.value: There are no experimental conditions - all participants responded to the same set of questions.

hypothesis.value:
In prior analysis of this data, we have found that those self-identifying as Republicans reported lower External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice (Plant & Devine, 1998) after the election of Donald Trump, while self-identified Democrats showed no such change. 
In the current analysis, we test whether this change in motivation further predicts changes in explicit attitudes towards African-Americans. Using a moderated-mediation framework, we predict that one’s political orientation predicts EMS, which predicts explicit attitudes, and that the relationship between political attitudes and EMS will change from before to after the election of Donald Trump (Republicans will report less EMS), which will predict increased prejudice against African-Americans for Republicans (but not for Democrats).

registration_responses.data: Yes, we already collected the data.
registration_responses.name: TrumpEMS Study 2
registration_responses.other:
While the underlying data have already been collected and made public, we have blinded ourselves to the relationship between our variables by creating two placebo DVs. We randomly reshuffled EMS across our cases, thus preventing us from learning anything about the predictive power of our mediator and covariates (since they were just predicting random noise, albeit random noise with the same distributional properties as our actual data) in the building of our models. After submitting this registration, we will then shift to the real variable and will run the registered models.
This registration is a follow-up to https://osf.io/6q25d, which we have already run. The ideas for this analysis came from discussions of those prior results at lab meetings and among the authors. We therefore know a little bit more about the data than in the previous analysis, where we were truly blind to the relationships between our variables - we know, for instance, that there was an interaction between political orientation and our time-changepoint for the prediction of EMS. However, we still do not know the relationships with the DV in this data.
registration_responses.sample: Our sample is based on those individuals with full data. We have 37,719 participants who meet our criteria, which gives us far better than 80% power to detect a mediation effect with small (standardized beta = 0.14) a and b paths (Fritz & MacKinnon, 2007)
registration_responses.analyses:
We are conducting a moderated mediation, with a time-dummy (coded as 0 if the response comes before the election of Donald Trump and 1 if the response comes from afterwards) moderating the mediational relationship where political orientation (binned as 0 if self-reporting Democratic leanings and 1 if self-reporting Republican leanings) -> (a path) -> changes in EMS -> (b path) changes in explicit attitudes.
We predict that these relationships will not hold in the same pattern for a parallel analysis using IMS as the mediator.

 See the commented analysis script in the Analysis component of this registration.
registration_responses.outliers: We will exclude any participants who do not have responses in our mediator as well as excluding those with missing values in our IV, or DV, or our demographic covariates. We will additionally exclude anyone reporting themselves to be politically neutral and will drop anyone reporting that they were born before 1925 (to exclude those individuals of high leverage who misunderstood our free-response age question).
registration_responses.dependent:
Our IV is binned political orientation, based on a 7-point question that asks respondents about their political leanings. We code those with Republican leanings (i.e. those answering from 1 to 3 on the scale) as 1, and code those with Democratic leanings (i.e. those answering from 5 to 7) as 0. We drop anyone who responded as Neutral (i.e. 4).
Our mediating variable is the Internal/External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice scale (Plant & Devine, 1998), which was collected from a random subset of participants who took the Race IAT on Project Implicit from 2015-2018. Specifically, we’re using the EMS subscale
Our DV is a composite of three explicit attitude variables - a difference-score for feeling thermometers towards black and white individuals (scored as white-black) and an explicit-preference item from 1 = “I strongly prefer African Americans to European Americans” to 7 = “I strongly prefer European Americans to African Americans.”). We standardized both the difference score and the explicit preference item, then averaged them together to create our DV.
registration_responses.conditions: There are no experimental conditions - all participants responded to the same set of questions.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In prior analysis of this data, we have found that those self-identifying as Republicans reported lower External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice (Plant & Devine, 1998) after the election of Donald Trump, while self-identified Democrats showed no such change. 
In the current analysis, we test whether this change in motivation further predicts changes in explicit attitudes towards African-Americans. Using a moderated-mediation framework, we predict that one’s political orientation predicts EMS, which predicts explicit attitudes, and that the relationship between political attitudes and EMS will change from before to after the election of Donald Trump (Republicans will report less EMS), which will predict increased prejudice against African-Americans for Republicans (but not for Democrats).

q1.value: Deficit Attention Disorder: Partisan Motivated Reasoning about Budget Deficits

q2.value: Ian G. Anson, John V. Kane

q3.value: This study seeks to better understand how partisanship and presidential incumbency shapes reactions to budget deficits and the national debt. In an online experimental framework, we plan to manipulate respondents' exposure to information about deficits and the debt over time, changing the emphasis on Republican (Democratic) presidential administrations' responsibility for conditions. Then, we expect to perform an examination of subgroups of experimental respondents, examining under what conditions treatments are more or less impactful on concern about deficits and the debt.

q4.value:
Baseline partisan effects
H1. We expect partisans to increase their concern about the deficit and the national debt when exposed to treatments in which the out-party is depicted as running deficits (relative to a condition in which the in-party is depicted as running deficits)
H2a. We expect independents to show no increase or decrease in their concern about deficits and the debt in response to either treatment.
H2b. We expect the strength of partisan loyalty (leaner, partisan, strong partisan) to be positively correlated with the strength of the treatment effect.

Republican and Democratic treatment effects
H3. We expect Republicans exposed to a treatment depicting Democratic presidents presiding over deficit and debt to increase their concern about deficits, relative to a treatment depicting Republican presidents doing the same
H4. We expect Democrats exposed to a treatment depicting Republican presidents presiding over deficit and debt to increase their concern about deficits, relative to a treatment depicting Democratic presidents doing the same

H5. We expect Republicans with fiscally conservative ideologies to exhibit similar treatment effects relative to other Republicans

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Two-group experimental treatment exposing respondents to a simple vignette about the deficit and the national debt.

q9.value: Simple randomization will be performed using Qualtrics' randomizer

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We have conducted a pilot study on Amazon MTurk (N = 1000) that is not included in this pre-registration. Data to be analyzed in the pre-registered portion of this study will be fielded on the Lucid platform.

question.value:
We will utilize the Lucid platform to gather responses from online respondents. We expect to reach a sample of roughly 5,000 respondents. Payment will be handled by Lucid. The sample consists of adults (18+) located in the United States. We have no other eligibility criteria.
The study is expected to be fielded during the week of February 17th, 2020.

q13.value: Our targeted N is 5000 U.S. adults. The sample is not clustered or multilevel.

q14.value: Based on a pilot test with an N of 1000, an N of 5,000 will provide sufficient power to distinguish treatment effects. We are also constrained by budget to 5,000, though such a sample is sufficient in most survey experimental settings for fine-grained distinctions between treatments (see Mullinix, Leeper, Druckman, and Freese 2015, Journal of Experimental Political Science 2(2)).

q15.value: Our stopping rule is based on the anticipated target of 5,000 respondents. We anticipate one single round of data collection over a short period of time, with no breaks or interruptions, paying respondents the totality of the money we possess for allocation to the recruitment process. The result should be a sample of roughly 5,000 respondents.

question.value:
We plan on manipulating exposure to the vignettes described in the attached file below "vignette for preregistration.docx".

The treatments take 4 levels.

In Treatment 1, we expose respondents to the vignette in which all bracketed text displays "Republican". 
In Treatment 2, we expose respondents to the vignette in which all bracketed text displays "Democratic".
In Treatment 3, we expose respondents to the vignette in which no bracketed text appears.
In Treatment 4, we do not expose respondents to the vignette.

With an N = 5,000, we randomly assign respondents to the treatments in an unbalanced fashion. Our treatment assignment is as follows:

T1: 1,875 respondents (3/8 of sample)
T2: 1,875 respondents (3/8 of sample)
T3: 625 respondents (1/8 of sample)
T4: 625 respondents (1/8 of sample)
Please see the attachment "variable descriptions.docx" for information.

We will create an additive index of several DV outcomes in order to assess the effects of our treatment on overall concern about budget deficits. We use Stata code notationbelow to describe this process, but the finished analysis need not employ Stata as the sole software for processing.

The variable names correspond to the variable descriptions in "variable descriptions.docx".

////////////CHUNK 1: Rescaling DVs///////////////////
revrs DV1
revrs DV3
revrs DV4
revrs DVpew
revrs DV5

//////CHUNK 2: Evaluate the correlation and alpha of these items//////////////
pwcorr revDV1 DV2 revDV3 revDV4 revDV5 revDVpew, sig star(.05) 
alpha revDV1 DV2 revDV3 revDV4 revDV5 revDVpew, item 


//////////////CHUNK 3: Create a combined scale "DVscale"//////////////////////
gen DVscale=revDV1+ DV2+ revDV3+ revDV4+ revDV5+ revDVpew

//Rescale to DVscale_01, which creates a continuous measure bounded by 0 and 1
gen DVscale_01=(DVscale-6)/21

We will test the hypotheses using the following statistical tests, as expressed below in Stata code. Note again that Stata need not necessarily be used as the software for the final analysis. The tests will be performed both as linear regressions and group-level comparison-of-means tests for the purposes of graphical analysis. However, both types of analysis should produce interchangeable results from a mathematical perspective.

In the analysis that follows, PID3 is a nominal three-point scale containing "Republicans", "Democrats", and "Pure Independents". PIDAny is a nominal binary scale containing "Partisans" and "Pure Independents". PIDStrength is a three-point scale which codes partisans into three categories: "Leaning", "Partisans", and "Strong Partisans", based respectively on the following code assignments from the 7-point PID scale in the variable descriptions:
{1,7} <- Strong Partisans
{2,6} <- Partisans
{3,5} <- Leaning Partisans
{4} <- Pure Independents (omitted).

Ideo3 is similarly a nominal scale containing "Conservatives", "Liberals", and "Moderates". Ideo7 is a seven-point ideological scale as described in "variable descriptions.docx".

//H1 and H2a
reg DVscale_01 i.Treatments i.PIDAny i.Treatments#i.PIDAny

//H2b
reg DVscale_01 i.Treatments i.PIDStrength i.Treatments#i.PIDStrength

//H3 and H4
reg DVscale_01 i.Treatments i.PID3 i.Treatments#i.PID3

//H5
reg DVscale_01 i.Treatments i.Ideo3 i.Treatments#i.Ideo3
reg DVscale_01 i.Treatments i.Ideo7 i.Treatments#i.Ideo7
reg DVscale_01 i.Treatments i.PID3 i.Ideo3 i.Treatments#i.Ideo3 i.Treatments#i.Ideo3 ///
     i.Treatments#i.PID3#i.Ideo3

We are especially interested in comparing conservative Republicans to other groups in the interactive model specified.

q20.value: Please see above for instructions on recoding the right hand side variables used for analysis.

q21.value:
We will employ standard two-tailed statistical tests of significance derived from the difference-of-means test (which are mathematically identical to the lincom tests of regression coefficients in the linear models described above). Our cutoff for statistical significance is p < 0.05. 

We do not expect to discount for tests of multiple conditions.

q22.value: We will not practice exclusion of data points on the basis of outlier tests or any other diagnoses, based on the best practices recommended by survey experimental practitioners.

q23.value: We will employ listwise deletion of respondents who do not complete the questions required for a) the DV battery and b) the variables Ideo3/Ideo7 and PID3.

q24.value: We anticipate providing exploratory tests of the individual items used to construct the DV scale DVscale_01. We also anticipate exploratory tests of hypotheses beyond H1-H5 which involve comparisons between T3 and {T1,T2} and T4 and {T1,T2}.

attributes.title: The Link Between Burnout and Job Performance: A Meta-Analysis

q1.value: The Link Between Burnout and Job Performance: A Meta-Analysis

q3.value:
This meta-analysis will study the link between burnout and job performance, through a systematic review and meta-analysis, in order to provide an up-to-date perspective. Therefore the research questions are as follows:

1. What is the link between each of the three dimensions of burnout and job performance?
2. What are some possible moderators of this relationship?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Random effects model meta analyses, on the link between job performance and each of the three burnout components, followed by moderator analyses, in each case.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
- A systematic review will be carried out, in order to identify and download all relevant studies. 
- The following databases will be searched: PsycINFO, Web of Knowledge, Proquest, Scopus, ScienceDirect
- All quantitative types of study designs reporting the relationship between burnout and job performance (e.g., correlational studies, longitudinal studies, etc.) will be included 
- To be included in this analysis, studies have to meet four criteria:

1. Studies should be held in an organisational environment. All studies targeting students will be excluded, however we will include any samples of working students, as long as the research was conducted in an organizational environment.
2. Studies should report the level of burnout, either as a global score, or any of its constituents.
3. Papers should include a measure of job performance. Both objective measures, and self-reports will be considered.
4. Studies should provide information regarding the strength of the association between burnout and job performance, even if it does not the main objective of the study (i.e., in the form of a correlation matrix).

q13.value: All the identified studies which meet the set inclusion criteria will be included in this meta-analysis.

question.value:
We will consider studies which measure burnout with either the MBI or OLBI questionnaires, as well as any other valid measure of the construct 

We will consider studies which measure both in-role and extra-role performance, measured both subjectively or objectively. 

The following moderators will be considered: type of performance (i.e., in-role, extra-role), type of performance report (i.e., subjective reports, objective reports), type of burnout measure (i.e., MBI, OLBI) and the participant occupation.

Individual study data will be pooled, effect sizes being calculated from the data, based on the sample and correlation values. The results will be converted into Fisher's Z, to for the non-normal distribution of Pearson’s r. For the instances in which the same construct reports multiple measures, statistical independence will be ensured by calculating an overall relationship, with one effect size per independent sample (Card, 2015). The Z’s (in other words, the standardised effect sizes) will then be weighted with the respective sample size and used to create a weighted mean Z. A random-effects meta-analysis will be conducted, using the metafor package in R (Viechtbauer, 2010). Heterogeneity will be assessed using a Q-test, T values and I² values. It will be considered meaningful for a significant Q-test result and an I² value greater or equal to 75%. A one-study-removed sensitivity analysis will be employed for detecting any potential outliers, or any study majorly influencing the obtained results. Lastly, funnel plots will be examined to determine the existence of publication bias.

q22.value: A one-study-removed sensitivity analysis will be employed for detecting any potential outliers, or any study majorly influencing the obtained results.

2. What are some possible moderators of this relationship?

attributes.title: IEMP North Indian Raga
attributes.description: A collection of audiovisual recordings of North Indian (Hindustani) Raga performances, with detailed annotations.

summary.value:
The IEMP North Indian Raga corpus comprises audiovisual recordings of eight
complete performances, recorded since 2005 in India and the UK. About half
were recorded in India using SD cameras (2005-2010), and the rest in the UK using
HD cameras (2012-2016), all with multitrack audio. 
The performers are all professional or semi-professional musicians, and all signed
release forms permitting non-profit educational and research use of the recordings
and were assured that full performances would not be published without their
further explicit consent. Usage of the recordings is in accordance with the
licence attached, which permits use for the purposes of not-for-profit research
or teaching or personal educational development.
Summary of contents
The music performed is North Indian (Hindustani) raga music, both vocal (mainly
khyal, with tabla and harmonium accompaniment) and instrumental (e.g. sitar,
sarod, slide guitar and sarangi with tabla accompaniment, or tabla solo with
harmonium accompaniment). A variety of ragas and talas are represented. 
The data consists of audio recordings, video recordings and associated data
including – depending on the recording - annotations of formal, metrical and
cadential structures, extracted onset data, and assigned and manually checked event
onset annotations (onset times and peak levels linked to metrical positions)

registration_responses.summary:
The IEMP North Indian Raga corpus comprises audiovisual recordings of eight
complete performances, recorded since 2005 in India and the UK. About half
were recorded in India using SD cameras (2005-2010), and the rest in the UK using
HD cameras (2012-2016), all with multitrack audio. 
The performers are all professional or semi-professional musicians, and all signed
release forms permitting non-profit educational and research use of the recordings
and were assured that full performances would not be published without their
further explicit consent. Usage of the recordings is in accordance with the
licence attached, which permits use for the purposes of not-for-profit research
or teaching or personal educational development.
Summary of contents
The music performed is North Indian (Hindustani) raga music, both vocal (mainly
khyal, with tabla and harmonium accompaniment) and instrumental (e.g. sitar,
sarod, slide guitar and sarangi with tabla accompaniment, or tabla solo with
harmonium accompaniment). A variety of ragas and talas are represented. 
The data consists of audio recordings, video recordings and associated data
including – depending on the recording - annotations of formal, metrical and
cadential structures, extracted onset data, and assigned and manually checked event
onset annotations (onset times and peak levels linked to metrical positions)
